ol.li: Learn how to add and scalar-multiply vectors in \R^n, both algebraically and geometrically.

subsection.title: Vectors in \R^n
subsection.p: We have been drawing elements of \R^n as points in the line, plane, space, etc. We can also draw them as arrows.

statement.p: A point is an element of \R^n, drawn as a point (a dot).
A vector is an element of \R^n, drawn as an arrow.

subsection.p: The difference is purely psychological: points and vectors are both just lists of numbers.
When we think of an element of \R^n as a vector, we will usually write it vertically, like a matrix with one column: v = \vec{1 3}.

Why make the distinction between points and vectors? A vector need not start at the origin: it can be located anywhere! In other words, an arrow is determined by its length and its direction, not by its location. For instance, these arrows all represent the vector \color{seq-green}\vec{1 2}.

paragraphs.p: Unless otherwise specified, we will assume that all vectors start at the origin.

remark.p: Vectors makes sense in the real world: many physical quantities, such as velocity, are represented as vectors. But it makes more sense to think of the velocity of a car as being located at the car.

Some authors use boldface letters to represent vectors, as in "\mathbf v", or use arrows, as in "\oldvec v". As it is usually clear from context if a letter represents a vector, we do not decorate vectors in this way.

subsection.p: Another way to think about a vector is as a difference between two points, or the arrow from one point to another. For instance, \vec{1 2} is the arrow from (1,1) to (2,3).

subsection.title: Vector Algebra and Geometry
subsection.p: Here we learn how to add vectors together and how to multiply vectors by numbers, both algebraically and geometrically.

statement.p:
We can add two vectors together: \vec{ a b c} + \vec{ x y z} = \vec{ a+x b+y c+z}.
We can multiply, or scale, a vector by a real number c: \def\r{\textcolor{red}} \r c\vec{ x y z} = \vec{ \r c\cdot x \r c\cdot y \r c\cdot z}. We call c a scalar to distinguish it from a vector. If v is a vector and c is a scalar, then cv is called a scalar multiple of v.
Addition and scalar multiplication work in the same way for vectors of length n.

paragraphs.title: The Parallelogram Law for Vector Addition
paragraphs.p: Why? The width of v+w is the sum of the widths, and likewise with the heights.

figure.caption: The parallelogram law for vector addition.

paragraphs.title: Vector Subtraction
paragraphs.p: Why? If you add v-w to w, you get v.

paragraphs.title: Scalar Multiplication
paragraphs.p: A scalar multiple of a vector v has the same (or opposite) direction, but a different length. For instance, 2v is the vector in the direction of v but twice as long, and -\frac 12v is the vector in the opposite direction of v, but half as long. Note that the set of all scalar multiples of a (nonzero) vector v is a line.

subsection.title: Linear Combinations
subsection.p: We can add and scalar multiply vectors in the same equation.

statement.p:
Let c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_p be scalars, and let v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p be vectors in \R^n. The vector in \R^n c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_pv_p
is called a linear combination of the vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p, with weights or coefficients c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_p.

subsection.p: Geometrically, a linear combination is obtained by stretching / shrinking the vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p according to the coefficients, then adding them together using the parallelogram law.

example.p: Let v_1 = \vec{1 2} and v_2 = \vec{1 0}. Here are some linear combinations of v_1 and v_2, drawn as points.
The locations of these points are found using the parallelogram law for vector addition. Any vector on the plane is a linear combination of v_1 and v_2, with suitable coefficients.

figure.caption: Linear combinations of two vectors (in \R^3 instead of \R^2): move the sliders to change the coefficients of v_1 and v_2. Note that any vector on the plane can be obtained as a linear combination of v_1,v_2 with suitable coefficients.
Linear combinations of three vectors: move the sliders to change the coefficients of v_1,v_2,v_3. Note how the parallelogram law for addition of three vectors is more of a "parallepiped law".

paragraphs.title: Linear Combinations of a Single Vector
paragraphs.p:
A linear combination of a single vector v = \vec{1 2} is just a scalar multiple of v. So some examples include v=\vec{1 2},\quad \frac 32v=\vec{3/2 3},\quad -\frac12v = \vec{-1/2 -1},\quad\ldots
The set of all linear combinations is the line through v. (Unless v=0, in which case any scalar multiple of v is again 0.)

paragraphs.title: Linear Combinations of Collinear Vectors
paragraphs.p: The difference between this and is that both vectors lie on the same line. Hence any scalar multiples of v_1,v_2 lie on that line, as does their sum.
